ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Review of basic biochemistry. More in-depth knowledge about the structural features of proteins (some RNA). A thorough survey of X-ray crystallography and Cryo-EM.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Yong's segment of the course was a great introduction to X-ray crystallography and Cryo-EM. As someone who does not personally conduct structural biology research, I found it very valuable to learn how these two important techniques actually worked. His segment of the course along makes this class worth taking for anyone interested in learning about structural biology. The TA's for the class (Chris and Josh) were also exceptional and incredibly dedicated.

Weaknesses: Overall, the course was pretty disorganized. Lectures between different faculty members did not necessarily hold together cohesively in a continuous thread. Also, the nature of the problem sets and exams also varied greatly depending on the professor. Increased coordination between the different professors would have been much appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to anyone interested in structural biology (specifically x-ray diffraction and cryo-EM). Yong does a great job covering those topics, and you will definitely come away from the course with a greater understanding of how they work.
